section.title: Release Bundle Downloads
section.para: The Hibernate team provides release bundles hosted on the SourceForge File Release System, in ZIP and TGZ formats. Each release bundle containsJARs, documentation, source code, and other information.
You can download releases of Hibernate, in your chosen format, from the list at .

listitem.para: hibernate3.jar is an aggregation of all the Hibernate Core classes. This must be included in your project's classpath.
The lib/required/ directory contains JARs Hibernate requires. All the jars in this directory must also be included in your project's classpath as well.

important.para:
The slf4j JAR has additional requirements for it to function properly. The exact requirements depend on your logging back-end. See slf4j site
for details.

listitem.para: The /lib/jpa/ directory contains the JPA API JAR. This JAR needs to be in your project's classpath if you want to use the JPA APIs or JPA annotations.

section.title: Maven Repository Artifacts

note.para: The authoritative repository for Hibernate artifacts is the JBoss Maven repository. The team responsible for the JBoss Maven repository maintains a number of Wiki pages that contain important information.

listitem.para: - General information about the repository.
- Information about setting up the JBoss repositories in order to do development work on JBoss projects themselves.
- Information about setting up access to the repository to use JBoss projects as part of your own software.

section.para: Hibernate produces a number of artifacts (all under the org.hibernate groupId):

listitem.para: The main artifact, which contains all the Hibernate classes, in packageorg.hibernate. You need these to build applications using the native Hibernate APIs. It includes capabilities for using native Hibernate mapping in hbm.xml files, as well as annotations.
Represents Hibernate's implementation of JPA, as specified at .

This artifact depends on both hibernate-core and hibernate-entitymanager.
